head.title: Going Online To See Bus Systems (Not System Buses)

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Technology, Telecommunications and Internet
Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Manufacturing, Operations and Logistics

hedline.hl1: Going Online To See Bus Systems (Not System Buses)

abstract.p: British Bus Archives Web site offers information and photos pertaining to Britain's historic passenger buses; photo (S)

block.p: W. E. Moore started one of the earliest public transportation lines in Britain in 1815, with three donkeys and a cart. The company first delivered packages in an area centered around the English town of Colchester and started carrying people around 1865. Horse-drawn passenger service started in 1881, and a Clarkson steam passenger bus began running in 1914. The company lasted more than 150 years and was eventually purchased in 1963.

The history of the Moore Brothers company and of several other fleets is online at the British Bus Archives (www.britishbus.co.uk /index.html), with pictures of motorized coaches, double-decker buses and trams, articles by bus fans and links to more than a dozen museums.
SHELLY FREIERMAN
Browser A selection of events and sites on the Web.
Events
TODAY, 9 p.m. chat.msn.com
Coolio, the hip-hop artist, chats about some of his favorite Thai recipes, which are featured in a cookbook by the chef Harry Schwartz.

A chat with K. D. Lang about her new album, ''Invincible Summer.''
TUESDAY, 8 p.m. chat.msn.com/msnlive/
A chat with Venus Williams, who won her first Grand Slam event, the Wimbledon women's championship, last month.
Sites
www.africam.com Webcams set up near watering holes and migration areas in African preserves, plus conservation news, at AfriCam International.
soar.berkeley.edu/recipes/fruits/indexall.html A collection of recipes for fruit -- dried, curried, pickled, baked, diced, sliced, stuffed, sauced, poached and even skewered.

www.nhc.noaa.gov/index.html The National Hurricane Center tracks storm activity in the Atlantic, Carribean and Pacific Oceans. With satellite images, historical information and a list of storm names through 2005.

W. E. Moore started one of the earliest public transportation lines in Britain in 1815, with three donkeys and a cart. The company first delivered packages in an area centered around the English town of Colchester and started carrying people around 1865. Horse-drawn passenger service started in 1881, and a Clarkson steam passenger bus began running in 1914. The company lasted more than 150 years and was eventually purchased in 1963.

The history of the Moore Brothers company and of several other fleets is online at the British Bus Archives (www.britishbus.co.uk /index.html), with pictures of motorized coaches, double-decker buses and trams, articles by bus fans and links to more than a dozen museums.
